holdings.text: The requirement in section 5A(1) that the Collector record reasons for his opinion that delay under section 3 would adversely affect lands is mandatory, not directory.

anchor.surface_text: the question however debated before us was that the condition or the requirement was not mandatory what was only directory with the result that the failure on the part of the Collector to record

holdings.reasoning_summary: Depends on purpose, context, scheme of Act; departure from normal ss.3-5 procedure requires reasons as only safeguard against abuse; shall is mandatory here unlike directory precedents.

holdings.text: Failure to record reasons as required by section 5A renders the orders under section 5A null and void.

anchor.surface_text: if in those circumstances the section requires what might be termed a speaking order before persons are saddled with liability we consider that the object with which the provision

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandatory condition precedent; non-compliance makes orders without jurisdiction and of no effect; agrees with High Court.

holdings.text: This is the proper construction of section 5A: emergency power bypassing ss.3-5 only if reasons recorded mandatorily.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasons must be in order itself; reports provide material but not Collector's recorded reasons for urgency; distinguishes conclusion from grounds.

holdings.text: High Court has jurisdiction under Article 226 to quash demands under sections 11 and 12 without setting aside underlying void section 5A orders.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quashed illegal demands based on void orders; void orders need no setting aside; jurisdiction over demands clear.

holdings.text: Article 226 jurisdiction applies to quash post-Constitution demands based on pre-Constitution section 5A orders if demands illegal.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that all the several demands which were quashed were made after rejected the constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Demands post-Constitution; based on void orders hence illegal; no retrospectivity issue.

holdings.text: Respondents not estopped from challenging section 5A orders by acquiescence or benefit.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No notice under s.5A before work; precludes objection; anomalous to estop for not objecting.

holdings.text: Section 5B does not provide remedy to landlords against liability for apportioned costs under sections 7,8,11,12.

holdings.text: Availability of remedy under section 46 does not bar writ under Article 226.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Not pressed; High Court discretion even with alternatives.

holdings.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that these appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected; High Court correct on s.5A construction.
